content.description: Sit start five feet left of Fisher Fissure V3 on odd angle jugs and awkward feet. Pull up and lay-back the OK side-pull in the crack, then do some fancy foot work and move right hand further up the crack. From here there is multiple ways to get to the top, either employing a small crimp or a lay-back, the top out is huge! Walk of the other side.
content.protection: Pad and spotter because of a swinging fall potential.
content.location: five feet left of Fisher Fissure V3

content.description:
This is basically the direct line of '3 Speed On Vinyl' (aka 'Medicine Man'). Start standing on the large chalked jug shelf (same start as '3 Speed'). Grab a sidepull crimp with your left hand, move your feet around and do a foot/hand match with your right heel on the starting hold. Rock up and reach high to a good right sidepull (crux). Bump left hand to another good edge. From here, the top out is relatively straight forward on good holds. This problem is more logical and less contrived than '3 Speed' and is definitely easier. The landing is flat, the movement is great and it's just high enough to add some excitement.  

  I'm not sure if this problem has been done before. If it has, feel free to let me know and I'll change the info to match that. Based on the condition of the top out holds, I would guess that if it has been climbed before, that hasn't happened in quite a while...
content.protection: A couple of pads are sufficient.
content.location: This problem starts the same as '3 Speed', but goes directly up. It more or less faces 'Zig Zag Crack'.

content.description:
Do you like slab boulder problems that lead you pretty far off the deck? If so do this route. 

  Start on an easy ramp in the middle of the boulder  and work up right on the ramp. When the ramp ends make crux moves onto the face working straight up the face. At the bulge at the top Tim went left. 

  This route is a fairly dirty still, but I plan to clean this along with the route to the left. 

  My friend Tim, who is pictured, possibly did the FA, in the photos shown. I cannot confirm this so I didn't list it.
content.protection: Pads, spotter, not falling from the top.
content.location: On the Fissure Block this route is on the face that faces Pyramid Power (V8). Start on a small ramp and head straight up the face just to the right of Nala.

content.description:
Climb up the slab with the crux being in the bottom third, then a mental crux closer to the top. Using crimp, side pulls, smears and little nub make progress up the slab until you hit the easy top out. 

  The route could use a good cleaning but it still fun and doable in the condition it is in.
content.location:
Just around the corner to the right of Fishure Feature is the climb. Climb the left side of the slab past crimps. 

  If you stand with your back touchhing pyramid power you will be looking at this route.

content.description:
Start under the boulder, with a hand on the arete, from here you will want to pull up and pop to a ledge like feature, from here you will surmount the  bulge, onto the face that is fairly crimpy, but the hardest moves are certainly the first few moves. This route because it is overhung close to the ground at the start, it is often wet or dirty so i would suggest if you plan to do this route bring a brush, as it will make it more enjoyable. 

  This is another route that the starting hold has broken on which makes it harder, i have not done it since the hold broke so i cannot say how much harder, so if anyone has any info left me know.
content.location: In "cave" like feature facing the path.

content.description:
Sit start with left hand on weird side-pull and right hand around the arete pull up to the rectangle hold that always has chalk on it, then work your way up to the top, using heel hooks and compression. 

  This route used to be a mediocre V3 but a couple winters ago the starting jugs exfoliated leaving it in it's current state. It was done from a sit start to the top last fall and is said to go as a classic V6.
content.location: Walk the main trail through Black Jack Boulders and after The Big Dill break right and there is the problem. It is the right most crack route.

content.description:
Stand start on the shelf and move right to an undercling the stand up to the crimp . from here get some high feet and throw up to the sidepull/jug. from he grab a small crimp and huck to the jugs above. 

  This is called Medicine Man in the Kemple guide and giving a rating of V3/V4 but, but this is the proper rating and name.
content.location: Northwest side of boulder, facing Zig-Zag Crack

content.description:
This route starts on the sloping jug as for # Speed on Vinyl, but instead of going right go left heading for the juggy groove. To do this make a long span move (crux) to a crimp then bumping to the juggy groove. Then topping out. 

  The feet are good the span move is just really long it was my full span and I'm 6 feet tall with a +1 reach.
content.location: On the face that faces Zig Zag Crack going left from the jug that starts 3 Speed on Vinyl.

content.description:
This is a large boulder found within the Zig Zag Area. It is home to many great boulder problems that see a lot of traffic and a handful of climbs that don't see as much. "Fisher Fissure" and "Three Speed on Vinyl" are the two most popular climbs on this behemoth, but the great line "Into the Greening Silence" is not to be overlooked. This large boulder also has a few more problems waiting to seek attention.  

  There is also an additional giant boulder that lies behind the climb "Three Speed on Vinyl", this boulder has a few climbs on it, but many have yet to be recorded. Those climbs can be grouped within this sub-area.
